What is this blocked on?

This is happening for 1.4.12 as well as 1.4.14. And it's pretty easy to reproduce using https://github.com/electron/electron-quick-start

just add a {frame: false} option to BrowserWindow, and maximize the window using
require('electron').remote.getCurrentWindow().maximize()
If you have multiple monitors, you'll see a white edge on the other display

![image 1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/203771/21951243/c57acf5c-d9b8-11e6-96e5-c09840026bf1.jpeg)
![image 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/203771/21951245/c59db0e4-d9b8-11e6-9f0d-83e9174916ec.jpeg)

@fantasticsid what is your DPI set to? I may have a fix for this. See https://github.com/electron/electron/pull/8404

cc: @MarshallOfSound

The root cause for this issue happening on multiple monitors having this issue can be read about here:
https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/oldnewthing/20120326-00/?p=8003

When the window is maximized and the window **thinks it has a frame**, Windows will actually position the window offscreen (so that the "frame" doesn't show). There are then two approaches for solving in electron:
1. Update [native_window_views_win.cc](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/atom/browser/native_window_views_win.cc#L89) and handle the `WM_GETMINMAXINFO` event in `PreHandleMSG()`.  You'll be able to [get the coords](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms632626(v=vs.85).aspx) from the `l_param` and can update them to be the expected values (x/y of 0,0 instead of -7,-7) and set `*result` to 0 / return true.
2. In the constructor for [`native_window_views.cc`](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/atom/browser/native_window_views.cc#L283), unfortunately `WS_THICKFRAME` (among other styles such as `WS_CAPTION` and extended styles) are passed in (which trigger incorrect frame calculations). These styles can be removed completely and resizing still does work properly (at least in my testing). This would be my suggested approach.
